column1: Iliotibial band syndrome occurs when the ITB becomes swollen and irritated from rubbing against the bone on the outside of your knee.
The rubbing of the tendon can cause pain and swelling of the bursa, the tendon, or both.
Bending the knee over and over during these activities can create irritation and swelling of the tendon.
If you have iliotibial band syndrome you may notice: - Mild pain on the outside of your knee when you begin to exercise, which goes away as you warm up.
Iliotibial band syndrome can be treated with pain relievers and ice for pain.
For pain, you can use ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), naproxen (Aleve, Naprosyn), or acetaminophen (Tylenol).
- Talk with your doctor before using any pain medicines if you have heart disease, high blood pressure, kidney disease, or have had stomach ulcers or internal bleeding in the past.
